content:
Back in 2020 I wrote a blog post about the fact TLS 1.0 and 1.1 support ended with Thunderbird 68.4

The Thunderbird FAQ for the 78 release talks about it fairly extensively as a reason folk may not be able to get mail.

What has finally happened, years after they said they would also be ending support for TLS, Microsoft have finally bit the bullet and joined in something that had agreed to do years ago.

What does this mean for Thunderbird users. Well nothing as we do not support versions of Thunderbird that do not automatically support TLS version greater than 1.1. As Thunderbird has supported TLS V1.2 since Version 31.0, first offered to channel users on July 22, 2014 anyone with TLS issues from the Microsoft change is using software that has not been patched in about 8 years. THey have a lot of other issues, not just TLS.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Start *Windows'* safe mode with networking enabled - win10 https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode

Still In Windows safe mode, start thunderbird in safe mode - https://support.mozilla.org/kb/safe-mode-thunderbird

Does problem go away?

- If no, then cause is either: bug in Thunderbird, something (eg a setting, file or folder) in your Thunderbird profile, your mail provider. Please post into topic the contents of Help | Troubleshooting | copy text to clipboard

- If yes, the problem is gone, then (still in Windows safe mode) ... start Thunderbird normally -- If problem is still gone, then cause is a program loaded during windows startup. Possibilities include: antivirus SW, virus/malware, background downloads such as program updates -- If problem came back, then cause is likely a Thunderbird add-on - eliminate them by disabling add-ons one at a time in Tools | add-ons | extensions and restarting (or if you have many, disable multiple add-ons at a time)

- If results are unclear ... possibilities include temporary conditions such as contention from other running programs, downloads related to windows update, ...

Please let us know your findings.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Hi David,

Thank you for your message. Your requested made me to double check the HTML file. I created a signature file with Thunderbird editor and compared it with my file.

I discovered that the problem was the charset. I used the old version "charset=unicode" which apparently worked until recently, but now it must be UTF-8.

This solved the problem.

content:
Ciao, capita a volte che l'indice di Thunderbird si disallinei rispetto al contenuto reale dell'archivio. Quando capita succede che vengano mostrati risultati di email non più presenti perché ad esempi o cancellate. Di solito in questi casi la procedura da seguire è questa:

(1) esegui anzitutto una copia di backup del tuo profilo Thunderbird -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

(2) poi esegui la compattazione delle cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle

(3) prova quindi a ricreare l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
creator: @next

Ci serebbe il modo di recuperare per lo meno queste mail senza allegati? Grazie per la collaborazione.

Come dicevo sopra se una mail è presente nell'indice ma non nell'archivio, significa che è stata cancellata. Ne rimane traccia nell'indice o perché è sorto un problema di allineamento o semplicemente perché Thunderbird non ha ancora avuto il tempo di aggiornare l'indice.

Può darsi che qualcosa sia recuperabile dal backup che ti ho detto di fare sopra, soprattutto se i tuoi account sono di tipo POP3. La procedura da seguire è sostanzialmente questa: https://radiofaro.neocities.org/kb/index/002.html

Ti consiglio però di fare questo tentativo in un profilo separato in modo da non modificare il tuo profilo attuale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/utilizzare-piu-profili#w_creare-un-profilo Se all'avvio di Thunderbird con questo nuovo profilo ti viene chiesto di creare un account, crea un account di tipo feed/rss.
creator: @next

content:
re :I set up Thunderbird on NEW HP laptop with Windows 11.

Check Firewall: Is Thunderbird set up as an allowed program? If no then please make sure Thunderbird is in the list of allowed programs.

Do you allow the Anti-Virus product to scan incoming mail? It's possible the AV has intervened and scanning the image so the display got interupted.

Image attachments can be displayed if 'View' > 'display Attachments Inline' is selected, so I need to know if image is inline or an attachment. Is that image an attachment or embedded inline as part of the email ?

check you have this setting: View > Message Body As > Original HTML

Have you got the settings set up to download full copies or only headers meaning the email is retrieved and downloaded on demand ? Is there a restriction on downloaded file size?

Account Settings

  • 'Synchronisation & Storage' for imap account
  • Select 'Keep messages in all folders for this account on this computer'
  • click on 'Advanced.,.' button
  • Make sure all the folders are selected to do a full download. Any folder not selected will only download headers and click on OK

Under 'Disk Space'

  • Select 'Synchronise all messages locally regardless of age'
  • Suggest you do NOT select the checkbox 'don't download messages larger than X kb'


Located some useful information:

  • https://kb.mozillazine.org/Entire_message_fetched_when_opening_an_IMAP_message

mail.imap.mime_parts_on_demand defaults to true. It specifies that Thunderbird should analyze the messages headers if the message size is larger than mail.imap.mime_parts_on_demand_threshold , and fetch only the pieces of the message that will be displayed online.

In my case the Threshold is 500000 = 500 KB

Menu icon > Settings > General Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button It opens in a new tab. Try this: In search type: mime look for : mail.imap.mime_parts_on_demand on far right is the toggle icon - click on it to toggle the value to 'false'

Restart Thunderbird and test again.

content:
Okay, instead of importing, just copy the profile to somewhere on hard drive. The default location is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles but you're free to place elsewhere if desired, but using the default locatin has benefits as I will explain. If in default location, start Thunderbird, click help>moretroubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles'.. That should display the profiles found. Click yours to activate. If not shown, click the 'create profile ' button, clict next, enter a name for profile, (e.g. PROFILE) and after doing that click the browse button to select and activate your profile.

Another approach is to click the windows key and 'r' key to start profile manager (with thunderbird not running) and select profile that way. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hey David, Just catching up before bedtime. Hope to give it a try in the morning. Thanks!

Edit: The Morning After

Well, it worked so a big THANK YOU! But took a little playing around....

I copied my profile (named hero) into the Appdata folder with the existing profiles.

I got to about:profiles, but it wouldn't let me open hero - I could point to it via the open dialog, but no action would open it.

So I eventually selected Create a New Profile. I was able to enter the name hero1, and it created s0a9bfh6.hero1. but it still wasn't my hero*.

So I renamed the new Tbird-created profile s0a9bfh6.heroxxx and renamed my original hero to s0a9bfh6.hero1 and BINGO!

  • Disclaimer: My name choice was not a smarta__ attempt at cute, but was based on my new motherboard brand.

content:
Ciao, che io ricordi Thunderbird non ha mai avuto una funzione nativa di sincronizzazione dei contatti. Esistono invece delle estensioni che possono essere utilizzate a questo scopo ma funzionano solo con alcuni provider email. Ad esempio per sincronizzare la rubrica di Gmail con quella di Thunderbird esisteva gContactSync (https://addons.thunderbird.net/it/thunderbird/addon/gcontactsync/). Uso un verbo al passato perché questa estensione non è più compatibile con le ultime versioni di Thunderbird.

Esiste invece la possibilità di importare in Thunderbird una rubrica esportata da altro servizio. Basta aprire la rubrica di Thunderbird e premere il pulsante Importa

content: There is nothing more to say: if you want to use a calendar to store invitations you need to associate it with an email address. That's an email address of an account set up in Thunderbird.

content:
I can't see why it's now asking me if I want to accept invitations to calendars that aren't linked, and won't let me accept to a calendar that is linked.

I don't think I understand your setup. In any case, Thunderbird uses the email address an invitation (or cancellation) is sent to, and tries to match it to the email address assigned to a calendar. In your case there doesn't seem to be a match, hence the prompt.
creator: christ1

content: Since Thunderbird supports CalDAV natively now, that would be the preferred method to connect to a Google Calendar. So you just need to add a new Network Calendar, provide your Gmail email address, and Thunderbird will figure out the rest. Neither an add-on nor an URL is needed anymore. I think accessing a personal calendar from the corporate network can be problematic, because corporate IT may block things they deem inappropriate or potentially dangerous.
creator: christ1

Start Thunderbird with the new profile, and set up your calendar(s) there.

creator: jielink1978

content:
Ned89 ha detto
Dovrei astenermi dall'usare out.alice.it se, per adesso, l'unica maniera che ho trovato per utilizzarlo è tramite password su connessione non protetta e nessuna sicurezza della connessione? Ci sono informazioni (da te, da altri, in rete...) che possano guidarmi per essere più informato su questa mia specifica domanda?

Diciamo che la questione è complicata. I vecchi domini di posta tin.it ed alice.it sono un po' trascurati rispetto a tim.it. In teoria secondo la pagina https://www.tim.it/assistenza/assistenza-tecnica/mail/configurazione/protocolli-posta anche per gli indirizzi Alice.it dovrebbe essere necessario l'uso di una connessione cifrata (StartTLS). D'altro canto in altre sezioni https://img.tim.it/sdr/documenti/assistenza/Mobile/parametri-tim-mail.pdf invece per gli indirizzi Alice si parla di connessione non crittografata, cosa che hai evidenziato anche tu.

Una discussione tecnica sull’importanza di crittografare la connessione la trovi qui https://www.ilsoftware.it/articoli.asp?tag=Email-SSL-TLS-e-STARTTLS-Differenze-e-perche-usarli_13031

Se è disponibile nel tuo caso, potresti migliorare un po' la sicurezza impostando un numero di recupero https://www.tim.it/assistenza/assistenza-tecnica/mail/autenticazione/cellulare-recupero

Questa soluzione però può essere utile solo per recuperare l'accesso non previene il rischio di sottrazione delle credenziali attraverso la connessione non cifrata.

Personalmente arriverei a queste conclusioni:

  • Se la posta che ricevi sulla casella Alice è importante, non utilizzare la connessione in chiaro. Se non trovi il modo di far funzionare StartTLS/TLS, allora è molto più prudente se ti colleghi attraverso la webmail nel browser, dato che questa è protetta per tutti gli indirizzi del Gruppo TIM
  • Evita assolutamente di connetterti in chiaro attraverso reti non sicure (per esempio reti wifi pubbliche o comunque di terze parti)
  • Se invece la posta che ricevi su alice non è importante e se ti colleghi attraverso una rete fidata, potresti al limite anche continuare ad usare la connessione in chiaro.

content: Right-click the Inbox in the Folder Pane, Properties, and then the Quota tab (see picture for a gmail account). Not all servers support quotas, so you'll have to consult the provider's website. Note that in the case of gmail, the quota includes other services like Google Drive. The 'size on disk' of a folder, e.g. Inbox, is shown on the General Information tab of Properties.

content:
Even if you make a custom entry of 'Return-Path' there is no option to select a predefined list of email contacts. Again, I already tried all of this and it did not work. That is why I came here. That is why I said the 'Return-Path' needs to be added to the predefined options where it actually works. This is how some spam, scam and unwanted emails bypass being able to be blocked and force their way into our inbox. Also this is an email campaign designed to email multiple contacts all at once and that is why the BCC Field is being misused so there is no sender at all. If this problem is solved where we can use the 'Return-Path' as a criteria then this solves the loophole once and for all! So the rule would need to be as below... If the Email Sender is in a Contact List titled AutoDelete then Delete the Email If the Return-Path is in a Contact List titled AutoDelete then Delete the Email

  • Note: The same contact list is being used for both filter executions but right now this is not possible and that is what needs to change!
creator: technician1

content: The choices for Return-Path are contains, doesn't contain, is, isn't, begins with or ends with. If you wish to have additional terms, submit an RFE (request for enhancement) at Bugzilla. Using filters this way to block unwanted mail is usually an exercise in futility, but maybe you can use the custom headers as they are currently defined to achieve your objective.

content:
Did you perhaps skip a number of Thunderbird versions around 68? V68.5 made changes to the password store and if they were skipped the store is corrupted. existing entries are accessed and used but changes are not saved.

Try the solution I suggest here https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2022/10/thunderbird-passwords-not-saving.html
creator: MattAuSupport

I'm about ready to just forget it and continue to put in the password each time. I'm tired! It's not worth all of this trouble.
